Its unique character developed as a result of its geography at the confluence of European cultures. With origins in the culture of the [[Proto-Slavs]], over time Polish culture has been profoundly influenced by its interweaving ties with the [[Germanic languages|Germanic]], [[Latinate]] and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] worlds as well as in continual dialog with the many other ethnic groups and minorities living in Poland. The people of Poland have traditionally been seen as hospitable to artists from abroad and eager to follow cultural and artistic trends popular in other countries. In the 19th and 20th centuries the Polish focus on cultural advancement often took precedence over political and economic activity. These factors have contributed to the versatile nature of Polish art, with all its complex nuances. === Music === {{Main|Music of Poland}} {{multiple image | align = right | image1 = Frederic Chopin photo.jpeg | width1 = 150 | alt1 = Fryderyk Chopin | caption1 = [[Frédéric Chopin|Fryderyk Chopin]] was a renowned classical composer and virtuoso pianist. | image2 = Optreden Arthur Rubinstein in Concertgebouw, Bestanddeelnr 913-5228.jpg | width2 = 142 | alt2 = Artur Rubinstein | caption2 = [[Arthur Rubinstein|Artur Rubinstein]] was one of the greatest concert pianists of the 20th century. }} Artists from Poland, including famous musicians like [[Frédéric Chopin|Chopin]], [[Artur Rubinstein|Rubinstein]], [[Ignacy Jan Paderewski|Paderewski]] or [[Krzysztof Penderecki|Penderecki]] and traditional, regionalized [[folk music|folk composers]], create a lively and diverse music scene, which even recognizes its own music genres, such as [[sung poetry]] and [[disco polo]]. {{As of|2006}}, Poland is one of the few countries in Europe where [[rock and roll|rock]] and [[hip hop music|hip hop]] dominate over pop music, while all kinds of [[alternative music]] genres are encouraged.{{cite news |title=Sounds of Poland – day one: a history of Polish pop in 10 songs |work=Music |publisher=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/jun/06/sounds-poland-history-10-songs |author=Andrew Khan|date=2012-06-06 }} ''Also:'' {{cite web |title=Polish music now: from punk-folk to hip-hop |work=Music |publisher=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2012/jun/07/polish-music-piotr-metz |author=Piotr Metz |date= 7 June 2012}} The origins of Polish music can be traced as far back as the 13th century; manuscripts have been found in [[Stary Sącz]], containing [[polyphony|polyphonic]] compositions related to the Parisian [[Notre Dame School]]. Other early compositions, such as the melody of ''[[Bogurodzica]]'' and [[God Is Born]] (a coronation [[polonaise]] for Polish kings by an unknown composer), may also date back to this period, however, the first known notable composer, [[Mikołaj z Radomia|Nicholas of Radom]], was born and lived in the 15th century. During the 16th century, two main musical groups – both based in [[Kraków]] and belonging to the King and Archbishop of [[Wawel]] – led to the rapid development of Polish renaissance music. Composers writing during this period include [[Mikołaj Gomółka]], [[Wacław of Szamotuły]], [[Nicolaus Cracoviensis]], [[Marcin Leopolita]], [[Wojciech Długoraj]] and [[Jakub Polak (musician)|Jakub Polak]]. [[Diomedes Cato]], a native-born Italian who lived in Kraków from about the age of five, became a renowned lutenist at the court of Sigismund III, and not only imported some of the musical styles from southern Europe, but blended them with native folk music. {{Listen | header = '''[[Fryderyk Chopin]]''' | filename = Frederic Chopin - mazurka no. 4 in a minor, op. 17.ogg | title = Mazurka no. 4 in a minor, op. 17 | description = [[Mazurka]] ({{lang-pl|mazurek}}), stylized [[folk dance]] in [[triple meter]] (1832), commemorating the [[November Uprising]] | help = no | pos = left }} In the 17th and 18th centuries, renowned Polish baroque composers included [[Bartłomiej Pękiel]], [[Mikołaj Zieleński]], [[Marcin Mielczewski]], [[Adam Jarzębski]], [[Grzegorz Gerwazy Gorczycki]], [[Stanisław Sylwester Szarzyński]] and [[:pl:Andrzej Rohaczewski|Andrzej Rohaczewski]]. Most of the compositions written were either [[liturgical music]], or secular compositions such as [[concerto]]s and [[sonata]]s for voices or instruments. At the end of the 18th century, Polish classical music evolved into national forms like the [[polonaise]]. Also, [[Wojciech Bogusławski]]'s ''[[:pl:Krakowiacy i Górale|Krakowiacy i Górale]]'', which premiered on 1 March 1794, is regarded as the first Polish national [[opera]]. In the 19th century the most popular composers were: [[Józef Elsner]] and his pupils [[Fryderyk Chopin]] and [[Ignacy Feliks Dobrzyński]]. Important opera composers of the era were [[Karol Kurpiński]] and [[Stanisław Moniuszko]] whilst the list of famous soloists and composers included [[Henryk Wieniawski]], [[Juliusz Zarębski]]. At the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries the most prominent composers or musicians could said to have been [[Władysław Żeleński (musician)|Władysław Żeleński]] and [[Mieczysław Karłowicz]], [[Karol Szymanowski]] and [[Artur Rubinstein]]. [[Alexandre Tansman]] lived in Paris but had strong connections with Poland. [[Witold Lutosławski]], [[Henryk Górecki]], and [[Krzysztof Penderecki]] composed in Poland, [[Andrzej Panufnik]] emigrated. {{Listen | header = '''[[Ballades (Chopin)|Ballade form]] invented by [[Frédéric Chopin|Chopin]]'''.{{cite web | url=http://www.chopinmusic.net/works/ballades/ | title=Ballades (Frédéric Chopin) | work=Chopin Music | date=2004–13 | accessdate=7 January 2013 | author=Nico Paul}} | filename = Frederic Chopin - ballade no. 3 in a flat major, op. 47.ogg | title = Ballade no. 3 in a-flat major, op. 47 | description = Inspired by poems of [[Adam Mickiewicz]] | help = no | pos = right }} Traditional Polish folk music has had a major effect on the works of many well-known Polish composers, and no more so than on Fryderyk Chopin, a widely recognised national hero of the arts. All of Chopin's [[List of compositions by Frédéric Chopin|works]] involve the piano and are technically demanding, emphasising nuance and expressive depth. As a great composer, Chopin invented the [[musical form]] known as the [[ballade (classical music)#Instrumental ballades|instrumental ballade]] and made major innovations to the [[piano sonata]], [[mazurka]], [[waltz]], [[nocturne]], [[polonaise]], [[étude]], [[impromptu]] and [[prelude (music)|prélude]], he was also the composer of a number of polonaises which borrowed heavily from traditional Polish folk music. It is largely thanks to him that such pieces gained great popularity throughout Europe during the 19th century. Nowadays the most distinctive folk music can be heard in the towns and villages of the mountainous south, particularly in the region surrounding the winter resort town of [[Zakopane]]. Today Poland has a very active music scene, with the jazz and metal genres being particularly popular among the contemporary populace. Polish jazz musicians such as [[Krzysztof Komeda]] created a unique style, which was most famous in the 1960s and 1970s and continues to be popular to this day. Since the fall of communism throughout Europe, Poland has become a major venue for large-scale music festivals, chief among which are the [[Open'er Festival]], [[Opole Festival]] and [[Sopot Festival]]. === Art === {{Main|Art in Poland|Young Poland|List of Polish artists}} [[File:The Lady with an Ermine.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|''[[Lady with an Ermine]]'' (1490) by [[Leonardo da Vinci]]. Though not Polish in its origin, the painting symbolizes Poland's cultural heritage and is among the country's most precious treasures. The critics named it "a breakthrough in the art of psychological [[portrait]]ure."]] Art in Poland has always reflected European trends while maintaining its unique character. The [[Kraków Academy of Fine Arts]], later developed by [[Jan Matejko]], produced monumental portrayals of customs and significant events in Polish history.{{cite web|url=http://culture.pl/en/place/jan-matejko-academy-of-fine-arts|title=Jan Matejko Academy of Fine Arts – Place |publisher=Culture.pl|accessdate=31 August 2017}} Other institutions like the [[Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw]] were more innovative and focused on both historical and contemporary styles.{{cite web|url=https://asp.waw.pl/eng/history/|title=History|publisher=|accessdate=31 August 2017}} In recent years, art academies such as the [[Cracow School of Art and Fashion Design|Kraków School of Art and Fashion Design]], [[Art Academy of Szczecin]], [[University of Fine Arts in Poznań]] and [[Eugeniusz Geppert Academy of Fine Arts|Geppert Academy of Fine Arts in Wrocław]] gained much recognition. Perhaps the most prominent and internationally admired Polish artist was [[Tamara de Lempicka]], who specialized in the style of [[Art Deco]] and whose paintings are often collected by celebrities and well-known personas.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=QYHwLta1SooC&pg=PA47#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Madonna: A Biography|first=Mary|last=Cross|date=31 August 2017|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|page=47|accessdate=31 August 2017 |via=Google Books|isbn=978-0-313-33811-3}} Lempicka was described as "the first woman artist to become a glamour star."{{cite web |url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/madonnas-art-collection-277970 |title=Take a Look Inside Madonna's $100 Million Blue-Chip Art Collection |work=artnet News |date=17 March 2015 |accessdate=31 August 2017}} Another notable was [[Caziel]], born Zielenkiewicz, who represented [[Cubism]] and [[Abstraction]] in [[France]] and [[England]].{{cite web |url=http://www.whitfordfineart.com/artists/52-caziel/biography/ |title=Caziel biography |website=Whitford Fine Art |accessdate=31 August 2017}} Prior to the 19th century only [[Daniel Schultz]] and Italian-born [[Marcello Bacciarelli]] had the privilege of being recognized abroad. The [[Young Poland]] movement witnessed the birth of modern Polish art, and engaged in a great deal of formal experimentation led by [[Jacek Malczewski]], [[Stanisław Wyspiański]], [[Józef Mehoffer]], and a group of Polish [[Impressionists]].{{cite web|url=http://culture.pl/pl/tworca/jacek-malczewski|author=Jacek Malczewski| title= Twórca|publisher=Culture.pl|accessdate=31 August 2017}} [[Stanisław Witkiewicz]] was an ardent supporter of [[Realism (arts)|Realism]], its main representative being [[Józef Marian Chełmoński|Józef Chełmoński]], while [[Artur Grottger]] specialized in [[Romanticism in Poland|Romanticism]]. Within historically-orientated circles, [[Henryk Siemiradzki]] dominated with his monumental [[Academic Art]] and [[Roman Empire|ancient Roman]] theme.{{cite web|url=http://culture.pl/en/artist/henryk-siemiradzki|author=Henryk Siemiradzki |title= Artist|publisher=Culture.pl|accessdate=31 August 2017}} [[File:2658 Muzeum Narodowe. Foto Barbara Maliszewska.jpg|thumb|Interior of the [[National Museum in Wrocław|National Museum]] in [[Wrocław]], which holds one of the largest collections of contemporary art in the country.]] Since the inter-war years, Polish art and documentary photography has enjoyed worldwide fame and in the 1960s the [[Polish School of Posters]] was formed. Throughout the entire country, many national museum and art institutions hold valuable works by famous masters like [[Leonardo da Vinci]], [[Rembrandt]], [[Peter Paul Rubens]], [[Claude Monet]] and [[El Greco]]. Major museums in Poland include the [[National Museum, Warsaw|National Museum in Warsaw]], [[National Museum, Poznań|Poznań]], [[National Museum, Wrocław|Wrocław]], [[National Museum, Kraków| Kraków]], and [[National Museum, Gdańsk|Gdańsk]], as well as the [[Museum of John Paul II Collection]], and the [[Museum of King John III's Palace at Wilanów|Wilanów Museum]]. Important collections are also held in the [[Royal Castle, Warsaw|Royal Castle in Warsaw]], [[Wawel Castle]] and the [[Lazienki Palace]]. The most distinguished painting of Poland is ''[[Lady with an Ermine]]'' by Leonardo da Vinci, held at the [[Czartoryski Museum]] in [[Kraków]]. Although not Polish, the work had a strong influence on Polish culture and has been often associated with Polish identity.{{cite web |title=Lady with an Ermine – by Leonardo Da Vinci |url=https://www.leonardodavinci.net/lady-with-an-ermine.jsp |website=LeonardoDaVinci.net }} Other prominent 20th century artists originating from Poland include [[Magdalena Abakanowicz]],{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/21/arts/design/magdalena-abakanowicz-sculptor-of-brooding-forms-dies-at-86.html |title=Magdalena Abakanowicz, Sculptor of Brooding Forms, Dies at 86 |access-date=1 December 2017|newspaper=The New York Times |date=2017-04-21 |last1=Grimes |first1=William }} [[Tadeusz Kantor]],{{cite web|url=http://kumu.ekm.ee/en/tadeusz-kantor-member-of-the-polish-avant-garde-and-theatre-reformer/ |title=Tadeusz Kantor. Member of the Polish Avant-Garde and Theatre Reformer |access-date=9 December 2017}} [[Roman Opałka]],{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/art-obituaries/8725751/Roman-Opalka.html |title=Roman Opalka |access-date=1 December 2017|date=2011-08-26 }} [[Igor Mitoraj]],{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2014/oct/17/igor-mitoraj |title=Igor Mitoraj obituary |access-date=1 December 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |date=2014-10-17 |last1=Masters |first1=Christopher }} [[Zdzisław Beksiński]],{{cite web |url=http://culture.pl/en/article/the-cursed-paintings-of-zdzislaw-beksinski |title=The Cursed Paintings of Zdzisław Beksiński |access-date=1 December 2017}} [[Stanisław Ignacy Witkiewicz]]{{cite web |url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/poland/articles/the-story-of-witkacy-polands-restless-genius/ |title=The Story of Witkacy:Poland's Restless Genius |access-date=2018-03-31}} and [[Jean Lambert-Rucki]]. === Architecture === {{further|Category:Architecture of Poland}} Polish cities and towns reflect a whole spectrum of European architectural styles. [[Romanesque architecture]] is represented by [[St. Andrew's Church, Kraków]], and [[St. Mary's Church, Gdańsk]], is characteristic for the [[Brick Gothic]] style found in Poland. Richly decorated [[attic style|attics]] and [[arcade (architecture)|arcade]] [[loggia]]s are the common elements of the Polish Renaissance architecture, as evident in the [[Poznań City Hall|City Hall]] in Poznań. For some time the late renaissance style known as [[mannerism]], most notably in the [[Cracow Bishops' Palace in Kielce|Bishop's Palace]] in [[Kielce]], coexisted with the early baroque style, typified in the [[Saints Peter and Paul Church, Kraków|Church of Saints Peter and Paul in Kraków]]. {{multiple image | align = left | image1 = 20110917 Krakow Kosciol Mariacki 0306.jpg | width1 = 155 | alt1 = Saint Mary's Church in Kraków | caption1 = [[St. Mary's Basilica, Kraków|St. Mary's Basilica]] on the [[Main Market Square, Kraków|Main Market Square]] in [[Kraków]] is an example of [[Brick Gothic]] architecture. | image2 = Ayuntamiento, Poznan, Polonia, 2014-09-18, DD 67-72 HDR.jpg | width2 = 142 | alt2 = Poznań City Hall | caption2 = [[Ratusz]], the 16th-century [[Renaissance in Poland|Renaissance]] City Hall in [[Poznań]] designed by Italian masters. }} History has not been kind to Poland's architectural monuments. Nonetheless, a number of ancient structures has survived: castles, churches, and stately homes, often unique in the regional or European context. Some of them have been painstakingly restored, like [[Wawel Castle]], or completely reconstructed, including the [[Warsaw Old Town|Old Town]] and [[Royal Castle in Warsaw|Royal Castle]] of Warsaw and the Old Town of [[Gdańsk]]. The architecture of Gdańsk is mostly of the Hanseatic variety, a Gothic style common among the former trading cities along the Baltic sea and in the northern part of Central Europe. The architectural style of [[Wrocław]] is mainly representative of German architecture, since it was for centuries located within the Holy Roman Empire. The centres of [[Kazimierz Dolny]] and [[Sandomierz]] on the [[Vistula]] are good examples of well-preserved medieval towns. Poland's ancient capital, [[Kraków]], ranks among the best-preserved [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] and Renaissance urban complexes in Europe. The second half of the 17th century is marked by [[baroque]] architecture. Side towers, such as those of [[Branicki Palace, Białystok|Branicki Palace]] in Białystok, are typical for the Polish baroque. The classical [[Silesian architecture|Silesian baroque]] is represented by the University in Wrocław. The profuse decorations of the [[Branicki Palace, Warsaw|Branicki Palace]] in Warsaw are characteristic of the [[rococo]] style. The centre of Polish classicism was Warsaw under the rule of the last Polish king [[Stanisław II Augustus]].{{cite journal|last=Stanley|first=John|year=2004|title=Reviewed Work: Literary Activities and Attitudes in the Stanislavian Age in Poland (1764–1795): A Social System? by Jan I.J. van der Meer|journal=Canadian Slavonic Papers|volume=46|issue=1/2|pages=226–229|jstor=40870954|subscription=true}} The [[Łazienki Palace|Palace on the Water]] is the most notable example of Polish [[neoclassical architecture]]. [[Lublin Castle]] represents the [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] style in architecture, while the [[Izrael Poznański Palace]] in [[Łódź]] is an example of [[eclecticism]]. [[File:Kazimierz Dolny Market Square.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kazimierz Dolny]], the town exemplifies traditional provincial Polish folk architecture.]] Traditional folk architecture in the villages and small towns scattered across the vast Polish countryside is characterized by its extensive use of wood as the primary building material. Some of the best preserved and oldest structures include wooden [[Wooden churches of Southern Lesser Poland|churches]], and [[Wooden tserkvas of the Carpathian region in Poland and Ukraine|tserkvas]] primarily located across southern Poland in the [[Beskids]] and [[Bieszczady Mountains|Bieszczady]] regions of the Carpathian mountains.{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1053|title=Wooden Churches of Southern Małopolska|first=UNESCO World Heritage|last=Centre|website=whc.unesco.org}}{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1424|title=Wooden Tserkvas of the Carpathian Region in Poland and Ukraine|first=UNESCO World Heritage|last=Centre|website=whc.unesco.org}} Numerous examples of secular structures such as [[Dwór (manor house)|Polish manor houses]] (''dworek''), [[farmhouses]] ([[:pl:chata|''chata'']]), [[Granary|granaries]], [[Gristmill|mills]], [[barn]]s and country inns ([[:pl:karczma|''karczma'']]) can still be found across most regions of Poland. These structures were mostly built using the [[Log house|horizontal log technique]], common to eastern and northern Europe since the Middle Ages and also going further back to the old Slavic building traditions, exemplified by the wooden [[Gord (archaeology)|''Gród'']] (a type of fortified settlement built between the 6th and 12th centuries). These traditional construction methods were utilized all the way up to the start of the 20th century, and gradually faded in the first decades when Poland's population experienced a demographic shift to urban dwelling away form the countryside. === Literature === {{Main|Polish literature|History of philosophy in Poland}} The earliest [[Polish literature]] dates back to the 12th century, when Poland's official language was [[Latin]]. Within Polish literary customs, it is appropriate to highlight the published works concerning Poland not written by ethnic Poles. The most vivid example is [[Gallus Anonymus]], a foreign [[monk]] and the first chronicler who [[Cronicae et gesta ducum sive principum Polonorum|described Poland and its territories]].{{cite web|url=http://pamiecpolski.archiwa.gov.pl/objects/the-zamojski-codex|title=The Chronicle of Gallus Anonymus. The Zamojski Codex|first=Katarzyna|last=Szewczyk|website=pamiecpolski.archiwa.gov.pl|accessdate=24 May 2017}} {{multiple image | align = left | image1 = Adam Mickiewicz.PNG | width1 = 158 | alt1 = Adam Mickiewicz | caption1 = [[Adam Mickiewicz]] was an untiring promoter of Poland's culture and heritage. His [[Epic poetry|national epic poem]] ''[[Pan Tadeusz]]'' is considered a masterpiece of [[Polish literature]]. | image2 = Joseph Conrad.PNG | width2 = 132 | alt2 = Joseph Conrad-Korzeniowski | caption2 = [[Joseph Conrad]], one of the greatest novelists of all time. He was the author of popular books such as ''[[Nostromo]]'' and ''[[Heart of Darkness]]''. }} The first documented phrase in the [[Polish language]] reads "''Day ut ia pobrusa, a ti poziwai''" ("Let me grind, and you take a rest"), reflecting the culture of early Poland.{{cite web|url=http://scienceinpoland.pap.pl/en/news/news,370714,the-manuscript-with-the-first-ever-sentence-in-polish-has-be-digitalized.html|title=The manuscript with the first ever sentence in Polish has be [sic] digitalized – News – Science & Scholarship in Poland|first=Ideo Sp. z o.o. -|last=www.ideo.pl|website=scienceinpoland.pap.pl|accessdate=24 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821212328/http://scienceinpoland.pap.pl/en/news/news,370714,the-manuscript-with-the-first-ever-sentence-in-polish-has-be-digitalized.html|archivedate=21 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} It was composed by an abbot named Piotr (Peter) within the Latin language chronicle ''[[Liber fundationis]]'' from between 1269 and 1273, which described the history of the [[Cistercian]] monastery in [[Henryków, Lower Silesian Voivodeship|Henryków]], [[Silesia]]. The sentence was allegedly uttered almost a hundred years earlier by a [[Bohemia]]n settler, who expressed pity for his spouse's duty of grinding by the [[quern-stone]]. The sentence has been included in the [[Memory of the World Programme|UNESCO Memory of World Register]].{{cite web|url=https://poland.pl/tourism/unesco-sites/first-sentence-polish-unesco-register/|title=The first sentence in Polish in the UNESCO register|website=#Poland|accessdate=24 May 2017}} Most [[Middle Ages|medieval]] records in Latin and the [[Old Polish language]] contain the oldest extant manuscript of fine Polish [[prose]] entitled the ''[[Holy Cross Sermons]]'', as well as the earliest Polish-language bible, the so-called [[Bible of Queen Sophia]].{{cite web|url=http://polishlibraries.pl/article.php?a=14|title=Polish Libraries – Wiesław Wydra: The Oldest Extant Prose Text in the Polish language. The Phenomenon of the Holy Cross Sermons.|website=polishlibraries.pl|accessdate=24 May 2017}} One of the first printing houses was established by [[Kasper Straube]] in the 1470s, while [[Jan Haller]] was considered the pioneer of commercial print in Poland. Haller's [[Almanach cracoviense ad annum 1474|Calendarium cracoviense]], an astronomical wall calendar from 1474, is Poland's oldest surviving print.{{cite book|last1=Carter|first1=F.W.|title=Trade and Urban Development in Poland: An Economic Geography of Cracow, from Its Origins to 1795|date=2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-02438-9|page=364}} The tradition of extending Polish historiography in Latin was subsequently inherited by [[Vincent Kadłubek]], Bishop of [[Kraków]] in the 13th century, and [[Jan Długosz]] in the 15th century.{{cite web|url=http://www.polskieradio.pl/39/156/Artykul/1392738,Wincenty-Kadlubek-pierwszy-rodzimy-kronikarz|title=Wincenty Kadłubek – pierwszy rodzimy kronikarz|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2017}} This practice, however, was abandoned by [[Jan Kochanowski]], who became one of the first [[Renaissance in Poland|Polish Renaissance]] authors to write most of his works in Polish, along with [[Mikołaj Rej]].{{cite web|url=http://fp.amu.edu.pl/dwujezycznosc-w-tworczosci-jana-kochanowskiego/|title=Dwujęzyczność w twórczości Jana Kochanowskiego|website=fp.amu.edu.pl}} Poland also hosted a large number of famed poets and writers from abroad like [[Filippo Buonaccorsi|Filippo "Kallimach" Buonaccorsi]], [[Conrad Celtes]] and [[Laurentius Corvinus]]. A Polish writer who utilized Latin as his principal tool of expression was [[Klemens Janicki|Klemens "Ianicius" Janicki]], one of the most renowned Latin poets of his time, who was laureled by the [[Pope]]. Other writers of the Polish Renaissance include [[Johannes Dantiscus]], [[Andreus Fricius Modrevius]], [[Matthias Sarbievius]] and [[Piotr Skarga]]. Throughout this period Poland also experienced the early stages of [[Protestant Reformation]]. The main figure of Polish Reformation was [[John Laski]], who, with the permission of King [[Edward VI of England]], created the European Protestant Congregation of London in 1550.{{cite web|url=http://reformowani.org.pl/teologia/818-jan-laski|title=Jan Łaski – Parafia Ewangelicko-Reformowana w Warszawie|website=Parafia Ewangelicko-Reformowana w Warszawie|accessdate=24 May 2017}} [[File:Banquet in Nero's palace - Ulpiano Checa y Sanz.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|''Banquet in Nero's Palace'', an illustration from a 1910 print of ''[[Quo Vadis (novel)|Quo Vadis]]'', a historical novel written by [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel Prize laureate]] [[Henryk Sienkiewicz]].]] During the [[Polish Baroque]] era, the [[Jesuits]] greatly influenced Polish literature and literary techniques, often relying on God and religious matters.{{cite book |url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520233577 |title=Propaganda and the Jesuit Baroque |author=Evonne Levy |date=April 2004 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-23357-7 |accessdate=24 May 2017}} The leading baroque poet was [[Jan Andrzej Morsztyn]], who incorporated [[Marinism]] into his publications. [[Jan Chryzostom Pasek]], also a respected baroque writer, is mostly remembered for his tales and memoirs reflecting [[Sarmatism|sarmatian]] culture in the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]].{{cite web |url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jan-Chryzostom-Pasek|title=Jan Chryzostom Pasek |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=24 May 2017}} Subsequently, the [[Polish Enlightenment]] was dominated by [[Samuel Linde]], [[Hugo Kołłątaj]], [[Izabela Czartoryska]], [[Julian Ursyn Niemcewicz]] and two Polish monarchs, [[Stanisław I]] and [[Stanisław II Augustus]]. In 1776, [[Ignacy Krasicki]] composed the first proper [[novel]] entitled [[The Adventures of Mr. Nicholas Wisdom]], which was a milestone for Polish literature.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ue3cAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA166#v=onepage&f=false |title=The Encyclopedia of the Novel |editor=Peter Melville Logan |others=Associate editors:Olakunle George, Susan Hegeman, EfraÃn Kristal |year=2014|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|accessdate=24 May 2017|via=Google Books|isbn=978-1-118-77907-1 }} Among the best known [[Romanticism in Poland|Polish Romantics]] are the "[[Three Bards]]"–the three [[national poets]] active in the [[Partitions of Poland|age of foreign partitions]]–[[Adam Mickiewicz]], [[Juliusz Słowacki]] and [[Zygmunt Krasiński]].{{cite book|author=Eunice L. Blavascunas|title=The Peasant and Communist Past in the Making of an Ecological Region: Podlasie, Poland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZsEzM8Gbl68C&pg=PA98|year=2008|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=978-0-549-65633-3|page=98}} Adam Mickiewicz is widely regarded as one of the greatest Polish, [[Slavic language|Slavic]] and [[Europea]]n poets.{{cite web|url=http://culture.pl/en/artist/adam-mickiewicz|title=Adam Mickiewicz – Artist – Culture.pl|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.poemhunter.com/adam-mickiewicz/|title=Adam Mickiewicz – Adam Mickiewicz Poems – Poem Hunter|website=www.poemhunter.com|accessdate=24 May 2017}} He is known primarily for the [[Epic poetry|national epic poem]] ''[[Pan Tadeusz]]'', a masterpiece of Polish literature. A Polish prose poet of the highest order, [[Joseph Conrad]], the son of dramatist [[Apollo Korzeniowski]], won worldwide fame with his English-language novels and stories that are informed with elements of the [[History of Poland|Polish national experience]].{{cite web|url=http://www.josephconradsociety.org/|title=The Joseph Conrad Society (UK) Official Website|work=josephconradsociety.org|accessdate=10 February 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://josephconrad.org/|title=The Joseph Conrad Society of America|work=josephconrad.org|accessdate=10 February 2016}} Conrad's books and published novels like ''[[Heart of Darkness]]'', ''[[Nostromo]]'' and ''[[Victory (novel)|Victory]]'' are believed to be one of the finest works ever written, placing Conrad among the greatest novelists of all time.{{cite web|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Joseph-Conrad|title=Joseph Conrad |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=24 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://rawlangs.com/2012/12/27/multilingualism-and-literature-10-authors-who-write-in-other-languages/|title=Multilingualism and literature: 10 authors who write in other languages|date=27 December 2012|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404060256/http://rawlangs.com/2012/12/27/multilingualism-and-literature-10-authors-who-write-in-other-languages/|archivedate=4 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} In the 20th century, five Polish [[novelist]]s and poets were awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]]–[[Henryk Sienkiewicz]] for ''[[Quo Vadis (novel)|Quo Vadis]]'', [[Władysław Reymont]] for ''[[The Peasants]]'', [[Isaac Bashevis Singer]], [[Czesław Miłosz]] and [[Wisława Szymborska]]. ===Cinema=== {{Main|Cinema of Poland|Theatre of Poland}} [[File:Roman Polanski 2011 2. (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.72|[[Roman Polański]] is one of the most controversial and successful film directors, having received an [[Academy Award for Best Director|Academy Award]] and [[Palme d'Or]]. He directed ''[[Chinatown (film)|Chinatown]]'', ''[[The Pianist (film)|The Pianist]]'' and ''[[The Ghost Writer (film)|The Ghost Writer]]''.]] The history of Polish cinema is as long as history of [[cinematography]] itself. Over decades, Poland has produced outstanding directors, film producers, cartoonists and actors that achieved world fame, especially in [[Hollywood]]. Moreover, Polish inventors played an important role in the development of world cinematography and modern-day television. Among the most famous directors and producers, who worked in Poland as well as abroad are [[Roman Polański]], [[Andrzej Wajda]], [[Samuel Goldwyn]], the [[Warner Brothers|Warner brothers]] ([[Harry Warner|Harry]], [[Albert Warner|Albert]], [[Sam Warner|Sam]], and [[Jack L. Warner|Jack]]), [[Max Fleischer]], [[Lee Strasberg]], [[Agnieszka Holland]] and [[Krzysztof Kieślowski]]. In the 19th century, throughout partitioned Poland, numerous amateur inventors, such as [[Kazimierz Prószyński]], were eager to construct a film projector. In 1894, Prószyński was successful in creating a [[Pleograph]], one of the first cameras in the world. The invention, which took photographs and projected pictures, was built before the [[Lumière brothers]] lodged their patent.{{cite web|url=http://culture.pl/en/article/a-foreigners-guide-to-polish-cinema|title=A Foreigner's Guide to Polish Cinema |publisher=Culture.pl|accessdate=6 April 2018}} He also patented an [[Aeroscope]], the first successful hand-held operated film camera. In 1897, [[Jan Szczepanik]], obtained a British patent for his [[Telectroscope]]. This prototype of television could easily transmit image and sound, thus allowing a live remote view. Following the invention of appropriate apparatus and technological development in the upcoming years, his then-impossible concept became reality. [[File:Andrzej Wajda 1974.jpg|thumb|right|[[Andrzej Wajda]] was one of the greatest Polish film directors, and the recipient of a [[Honorary Oscar]], the [[Palme d'Or]], as well as Honorary [[Golden Lion]] and [[Golden Bear]] Awards.]] Polish cinema developed rapidly in the [[interwar period]]. The most renowned star of the [[silent film]] era was Polish actress [[Pola Negri]]. During this time, the [[Yiddish cinema]] also evolved in Poland. Films in the [[Yiddish language]] with Jewish themes, such as ''[[The Dybbuk (film)|The Dybbuk]]'' (1937), played an important part in pre-war Polish cinematography. In 1945 the government established '[[Film Polski]]', a state-run film production and distribution organization, with director [[Aleksander Ford]] as the head of the company. Ford's ''[[Knights of the Teutonic Order (film)|Knights of the Teutonic Order]]'' (1960) was viewed by millions of people in the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and France.{{cite web|url=https://www.phil.muni.cz/dedur/?lang=1&id=964|title=Film Culture: Brno 1945–1970. The History of Distribution, Exhibition and Reception|website=www.phil.muni.cz|accessdate=6 April 2018}} This success was followed by the popular historical films of [[Jerzy Hoffman]] and Andrzej Wajda. Wajda's 1975 film ''[[The Promised Land (1975 film)|The Promised Land]]'' was nominated at the [[48th Academy Awards]].{{cite web|url=https://thequietus.com/articles/16644-the-promised-land-review|title=The Quietus - Film - Film Reviews - Peasant Company Excepted: Andrzej Wajda's The Promised Land|website=The Quietus|accessdate=31 March 2019}} In 2015, ''[[Ida (film)|Ida]]'' by [[Paweł Pawlikowski]] won the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]].{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/ida-a-film-masterpiece|title="Ida": A Film Masterpiece|first=David|last=Denby|date=27 May 2014|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2018|via=www.newyorker.com}} In 2019, Pawlikowski received an [[Academy Award for Best Director]] nomination for his historical period drama ''[[Cold War (film)|Cold War]]''. Other well-known Polish Oscar-winning productions include ''[[The Pianist (2002 film)|The Pianist]]'' (2002) by Roman Polański. === Media === {{Main|Television in Poland|Media of Poland}} {{further|Category:Video gaming in Poland}} [[File:Siedziba Telewizji Polskiej w Warszawie 2017.jpg|left|thumb|Headquarters of the publicly funded national television network [[Telewizja Polska|TVP]] in Warsaw.]] Poland has a number of major media outlets, chief among which are the national television channels. [[Telewizja Polska|TVP]] is Poland's [[public broadcasting]] corporation; about a third of its income comes from a [[television licence|broadcast receiver licence]], while the rest is made through revenue from [[television advertisement|commercials]] and [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsorships]]. State television operates two mainstream channels, TVP 1 and TVP 2, as well as regional programs for each of the country's 16 [[voivodeship]]s (as [[TVP3|TVP 3]]). In addition to these general channels, TVP runs a number of genre-specific programmes such as [[TVP Sport]], [[TVP Historia]], [[TVP Kultura]], [[TVP Rozrywka]], [[TVP Seriale]] and [[TVP Polonia]], the latter is a state-run channel dedicated to the transmission of Polish language television for the [[Polish diaspora]] abroad. Poland has several 24-hour news channels: [[Polsat News]], Polsat News 2, [[TVP Info]], [[TVN 24]] TVN 24 Biznes i Świat, TV Republika and WPolsce.pl. [[File:Podczas zawodów IEM (8464360471).jpg|thumb|right|[[Intel Extreme Masters]], an [[eSports]] video game tournament in [[Katowice]].]] In Poland, there are also daily newspapers like ''[[Gazeta Wyborcza]]'' ("Electoral Gazette"), ''[[Rzeczpospolita (newspaper)|Rzeczpospolita]]'' ("The Republic") and ''[[Gazeta Polska Codziennie]]'' ("Polish Daily Newspaper") which provide traditional opinion and news, and [[tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloids]] such as ''[[Fakt]]'' and ''[[Super Express (newspaper)|Super Express]]''. ''Rzeczpospolita'', founded in 1920 is one of the oldest newspapers still in operation in the country. Weeklies include [[Tygodnik Angora]], [[:pl:W Sieci|W Sieci]], [[Polityka]], [[Wprost]], [[Newsweek Polska]], [[Gość Niedzielny]] and [[Gazeta Polska]]. Poland has also emerged as a major hub for video game developers in Europe, with the country now being home to hundreds of studios. |access-date=2018-09-07}} One of the most popular video game series developed in Poland includes ''[[The Witcher (video game)|The Witcher]]''.{{cite web |work=CNBC |date=14 Oct 2015 |title=Poland's video game sector powers up |author=Luke Graham |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/10/13/polands-video-game-sector-powers-up.html}} Other notable games include ''[[Bulletstorm]]'', ''[[Call of Juarez]]'', ''[[Painkiller (video game)|Painkiller]]'', ''[[Dead Island]]'', ''[[Lords of the Fallen]]'', ''[[The Vanishing of Ethan Carter]]'', ''[[Sniper: Ghost Warrior (video game)|Sniper Ghost Warrior]]'', ''[[Dying Light]]'', ''[[Shadow Warrior]]'', ''[[Gears of War: Judgment]]'', ''[[Observer (video game)|Observer]]'', ''[[Layers of Fear]]'', ''[[Book of Demons]]'' and ''[[Cyberpunk 2077]]''.{{cite news|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/poland/articles/7-highly-addictive-polish-video-games-you-should-try-out/ |title=7 Highly Addictive Polish Video Games You Should Try Out |access-date=2018-09-07}}{{cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/arts-entertainment/article/1843073/how-poland-has-turned-video-game-powerhouse |title=How Poland turned into a video game powerhouse |access-date=2018-09-07}} [[Katowice]] hosts [[Intel Extreme Masters]], one of the biggest [[eSports]] events in the world.{{cite web |work=Fortune |date=3 March 2016 |title=Poland Is Home to the Biggest eSports Event in the World |url=http://fortune.com/2016/03/03/poland-is-home-to-the-biggest-esports-event-in-the-world/ |author=John Gaudiosi }} === Cuisine === {{Main|Polish cuisine}} [[File:07425 Jahrmarkt in Sanok am 17 Juli 2011.jpg|thumb|left|Selection of hearty traditional comfort food from Poland including [[bigos]], [[cabbage roll]]s, [[żurek]], [[pierogi]], [[oscypek]] and specialty breads.]] Polish cuisine has evolved over the centuries to become very eclectic due to Poland's history. Polish cuisine shares many similarities with other [[Central Europe]]an cuisines, especially [[German cuisine|German]] and [[Austrian cuisine|Austrian]] as well as [[Jewish cuisine|Jewish]], [[Russian cuisine|Russian]], [[French cuisine|French]] and [[Italian cuisine|Italian]] culinary traditions. It is rich in meat, especially pork, chicken and beef (depending on the region) and winter vegetables (cabbage in the dish ''[[bigos]]''), and spices. It is also characteristic in its use of various kinds of [[noodle]]s, the most notable of which are [[kluski]], as well as [[cereal]]s such as ''[[kasha]]'' (from the Polish word [[kasza]]) and a variety of breads like the world-renowned [[bagel]]. Polish cuisine is hearty and uses a lot of cream and eggs. Festive meals such as the meatless Christmas Eve dinner (''[[Wigilia]]'') or [[Easter]] breakfast could take days to prepare in their entirety.{{cite web |url=http://www.polishcenter.org/Christmas/CHRISTMAS-ENG.htm |title=Traditional celebrations: Wigilia article from Pope John Paul II |website=Polish Center |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141130002746/http://www.polishcenter.org/Christmas/CHRISTMAS-ENG.htm |archive-date=30 November 2014 |publisher=Centrum Polonijne w Jorba Linda, California}} [[File:Bagel Bialy.JPG|thumb|right|[[Bagel]]s, made from [[yeast]]ed [[wheat]] dough, originated in Poland.]] The main course usually includes a serving of meat, such as roast, chicken, or ''[[kotlet schabowy]]'' (breaded pork cutlet), vegetables, side dishes and salads, including ''surówka'' {{IPA-pl|suˈrufka|}} – shredded root vegetables with lemon and sugar (carrot, celeriac, [[Searing|seared]] beetroot) or sauerkraut ({{lang-pl|kapusta kiszona}}, {{IPA-pl|kaˈpusta kʲiˈʂɔna|pron}}). The side dishes are usually potatoes, rice or ''kasza'' (cereals). Meals conclude with a dessert such as ''[[Cheesecake|sernik]]'' (cheesecake), ''[[makowiec (pastry)|makowiec]]'' ([[poppy seed]] pastry), or ''[[Napoleonka|napoleonka]]'' ([[cream pie]]), and tea. The Polish national dishes are ''[[bigos]]'' {{IPA-pl|ˈbiɡɔs|}}; ''[[pierogi]]'' {{IPA-pl|pʲɛˈrɔɡʲi|}}; ''[[kielbasa]]''; ''[[kotlet schabowy]]'' {{IPA-pl|ˈkɔtlɛt sxaˈbɔvɨ|}} [[breaded cutlet]]; ''[[gołąbki]]'' {{IPA-pl|ɡɔˈwɔ̃pkʲi|}} [[cabbage roll]]s; ''[[zrazy]]'' {{IPA-pl|ˈzrazɨ|}} [[roulade]]; ''[[roast|pieczeń]]'' roast {{IPA-pl|ˈpʲɛt͡ʂɛɲ|}}; sour [[cucumber soup]] (''zupa ogórkowa'', {{IPA-pl|ˈzupa ɔɡurˈkɔva|pron}}); mushroom soup, (''zupa grzybowa'', {{IPA-pl|ˈzupa ɡʐɨˈbɔva|}} quite different from the North American [[cream of mushroom soup|cream of mushroom]]); ''zupa pomidorowa'' [[tomato soup]] {{IPA-pl|ˈzupa pɔmidɔˈrɔva|pron}}; ''[[rosół]]'' {{IPA-pl|ˈrɔɕuw|}} variety of meat broth; ''[[żurek]]'' {{IPA-pl|ˈʐurɛk|}} sour rye soup; ''[[flaki]]'' {{IPA-pl|ˈflakʲi|}} [[tripe soup]]; ''[[barszcz]]'' {{IPA-pl|barʂt͡ʂ|}} and ''[[chłodnik]]'' {{IPA-pl|ˈxwɔdɲik|}} among others. Traditional alcoholic beverages include honey [[mead]], widespread since the 13th century, [[Beer in Poland|beer]], wine and [[vodka]] (old Polish names include ''okowita'' and ''gorzałka''). The world's first written mention of vodka originates from Poland.{{cite web |url=http://krps.pl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17&Itemid=27 |title=History of vodka production, at the official page of Polish Spirit Industry Association (KRPS), 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930131416/http://krps.pl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17&Itemid=27 |archivedate=30 September 2007}} The most popular alcoholic drinks at present are beer and wine which took over from vodka more popular in the years 1980–98. Tea remains common in Polish society since the 19th century, whilst coffee is drunk widely since the 18th century.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=UtA6-pyGJmMC&pg=PA692&lpg=PA692&dq=tea+19th+century+most+popular+in+poland&source=bl&ots=7GEQaW2La0&sig=ACfU3U0hNQSQITB8dWovFICqaznuHnUv9w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj5lOz8mKzhAhUbOisKHTStDGAQ6AEwE3oECAcQAQ#v=onepage&q=tea+19th+century+most+popular+in+poland&f=false|title=Polish Heritage Cookery|first1=Robert|last1=Strybel|first2=Maria|last2=Strybel|date=31 March 2019|publisher=Hippocrene Books|accessdate=31 March 2019|via=Google Books}} Other frequently consumed beverages include various mineral waters and juices, soft drinks popularized by the fast-food chains since the late 20th century, as well as [[buttermilk]], [[soured milk]] and [[kefir]].{{cite web|url=https://culture.pl/en/article/a-mini-guide-to-polish-dairy|title=A Mini-Guide to Polish Dairy|website=Culture.pl|accessdate=31 March 2019}} === Sports === {{Main|Sport in Poland}} [[File:Stadion Narodowy w Warszawie 20120422.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|left|The [[National Stadium, Warsaw|National Stadium]] in Warsaw, home of [[Poland national football team|national football team]], and one of the host stadiums of [[UEFA Euro 2012|Euro 2012]].]] [[Volleyball]] and [[Association football]] are among the country's most popular sports, with a rich history of international competitions. [[Track and field athletics|Track and field]], basketball, [[team handball|handball]], boxing, [[Mixed martial arts|MMA]], [[motorcycle speedway]], [[ski jumping]], [[cross-country skiing]], [[ice hockey]], tennis, fencing, swimming and [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]] are other popular sports. The most significant sportspeople from Poland include [[Robert Lewandowski]], [[Lukas Podolski]], [[Zbigniew Boniek]], [[Joanna Jędrzejczyk]], [[Marcin Gortat]], [[Robert Kubica]], [[Agnieszka Radwańska]], [[Kamil Stoch]], [[Justyna Kowalczyk]] and [[Irena Szewińska]]. The golden era of [[football in Poland]] occurred throughout the 1970s and went on until the early 1980s when the [[Poland national football team|Polish national football team]] achieved their best results in any FIFA World Cup competitions finishing 3rd place in [[1974 FIFA World Cup|the 1974]] and [[1982 FIFA World Cup|the 1982]] tournaments. The team won a gold medal [[Football at the Summer Olympics|in football]] at the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] and two silver medals, [[1976 Summer Olympics|in 1976]] and [[1992 Summer Olympics|in 1992]]. Poland, along with Ukraine, hosted the [[UEFA Euro 2012|UEFA European Football Championship in 2012]]. Retrieved 2 November 2014. === Fashion and design === {{Further|Category:Polish fashion}} [[File:Galeria Zielone Wzgórze, Reserved salon odzieżowy w Białymstoku.jpg|thumb|right|[[Reserved]] is Poland's most successful clothing retailer, operating over 1,700 stores across the world.]] Fashion was always an important aspect of Poland and its [[Culture of Poland|national identity]]. Poland belongs to one of the most [[fashion]]able and best-dressed countries in the world.{{cite web |website=My Dapper Self |url=http://mydapperself.com/top-10-countries-with-the-best-dressed-men/ |title=Top 10 Countries With the Best Dressed Men |date=21 September 2015 |author=Ed |accessdate=24 May 2017}} Although the Polish fashion industry is not as famed in comparison to the industries of France and Italy, it still contributed to global trends and clothing habits. Moreover, several Polish designers and stylists left a lifelong legacy of beauty inventions and [[cosmetics]], which are still in use nowadays. Throughout history, the clothing styles in Poland often varied due to foreign influence, especially from the neighbouring countries and the Middle East. Because of its geographical position, Poland was metaphorically referred to as a trade route that linked Western Europe with the [[Ottoman Empire]], [[Crimean Khanate]] and Persia. This allowed the Poles to absorb several habits, which were present in the Middle East at the time. The high-class [[Szlachta|nobility]] and [[magnate]]s wore attire that somewhat resembled oriental styles.{{cite web |author=Miltiades Varvounis |date=26 February 2015 |url=http://visegradinsight.eu/sarmatism-and-polands-national-consciousness26022015/ |title="Sarmatism" and Poland's national consciousness |website=Visegrad Insight |accessdate=24 May 2017}} The outfits included a [[Żupan]], [[Delia]], [[Kontusz]], and a type of [[Szabla|sword]] called [[Karabela]], brought by [[Armenia]]n merchants. Wealthy Polish aristocrats also kept captive [[Tatars]] and [[Janissaries]] in their courts; this affected the national dress. The extensive multiculuralism present in the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]] developed the ideology of "[[Sarmatism]]". [[File:Helena Rubinstein by Paul César Helleu (1859-1927) cropped.jpg|thumb|left|upright=.72|[[Helena Rubinstein]] by [[Paul César Helleu]], c. 1908.]] The Polish national dress as well as the fashion and etiquette of Poland also reached the royal court at [[Versailles]] in the 18th century. Some French dresses inspired by Polish outfits were called ''à la polonaise'', meaning "Polish-styled". The most famous example is the ''[[Polonaise (clothing)|robe à la polonaise]]'' or simply ''Polonaise'', a woman's garment with draped and swagged [[overskirt]], worn over an underskirt or [[petticoat]].{{cite web |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/polonaise-dress |title=Polonaise |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica |accessdate=24 May 2017}} Another notable example is the
